description: Jun. 5-- The NCAA Division I Council approved a waiver that will allow Central Michigan's football program to remain in the Football Bowl Subdivision and give the school two years to bring the total number of men's programs up to FBS compliance, athletic director Michael Alford announced Thursday. CMU fell beneath the FBS threshold requiring six men's programs...
text:
Jun. 5\--The NCAA Division I Council approved a waiver that will allow Central
Michigan's football program to remain in the Football Bowl Subdivision and
give the school two years to bring the total number of men's programs up to
FBS compliance, athletic director Michael Alford announced Thursday.

The waiver expires after the 2021-22 academic year.

"We continue to research and determine the best course of action to return the
department to full compliance," Alford said in a statement.

CMU fell beneath the FBS threshold requiring six men's programs when it
discontinued its men's indoor and outdoor track and field programs May 19 to
combat financial shortcomings during the coronavirus pandemic. In doing so,
CMU dropped from seven men's sports to five.

If the NCAA hadn't granted CMU relief, the university would have needed to add
another low-cost men's sport.

In April, the NCAA rejected a proposal from Group of Five conferences, which
includes the Mid-American Conference, requesting FBS requirements on varsity
sports be relaxed in wake of the pandemic, according to ESPN.

"As I have said throughout this process," Alford said, "through my various
conversations I felt confident that everyone involved was understanding about
our current financial situation and we look forward to returning to full
compliance."

The loss of men's track and field affected 36 student-athletes and is expected
to save the athletic department $620,000 annually.

Because of budget restrictions, 12 Division I universities have cut more than
20 athletic programs, beginning April 2 with Old Dominion's wrestling team.

Of those teams, only one -- Bowling Green baseball -- was reinstated. Alumni
and donors committed $1.5 million over the next three years to keep the
program alive while the university seeks long-term funding options.

Alford said men's track and field will not return, even if the financial
situation improves. There are no current plans to discontinue other sports.

The remaining 16 sponsored sports at CMU are men's and women's basketball,
football, women's soccer, women's golf, baseball, softball, men's and women's
cross country, field hockey, women's track and field, gymnastics, women's
lacrosse, volleyball and wrestling.

Evan Petzold is a sports reporting intern at the Detroit Free Press. Contact
him at [epetzold@freepress.com](mailto:epetzold@freepress.com) or follow him
on Twitter @EvanPetzold.

___

(c)2020 the Detroit Free Press

Visit the Detroit Free Press at www.freep.com

Distributed by Tribune Content Agency, LLC.

title: Central Michigan gets waiver from NCAA, won't lose FBS status [Detroit Free Press]
html:
Jun. 5--The NCAA Division I Council approved a waiver that will allow Central Michigan's football program to remain in the Football Bowl Subdivision and give the school two years to bring the total number of men's programs up to FBS compliance, athletic director Michael Alford announced Thursday.

The waiver expires after the 2021-22 academic year.

"We continue to research and determine the best course of action to return the department to full compliance," Alford said in a statement.

CMU fell beneath the FBS threshold requiring six men's programs when it discontinued its men's indoor and outdoor track and field programs May 19 to combat financial shortcomings during the coronavirus pandemic. In doing so, CMU dropped from seven men's sports to five.

If the NCAA hadn't granted CMU relief, the university would have needed to add another low-cost men's sport.

In April, the NCAA rejected a proposal from Group of Five conferences, which includes the Mid-American Conference, requesting FBS requirements on varsity sports be relaxed in wake of the pandemic, according to ESPN.

"As I have said throughout this process," Alford said, "through my various conversations I felt confident that everyone involved was understanding about our current financial situation and we look forward to returning to full compliance."

The loss of men's track and field affected 36 student-athletes and is expected to save the athletic department $620,000 annually.

Because of budget restrictions, 12 Division I universities have cut more than 20 athletic programs, beginning April 2 with Old Dominion's wrestling team.

Of those teams, only one -- Bowling Green baseball -- was reinstated. Alumni and donors committed $1.5 million over the next three years to keep the program alive while the university seeks long-term funding options.

Alford said men's track and field will not return, even if the financial situation improves. There are no current plans to discontinue other sports.

The remaining 16 sponsored sports at CMU are men's and women's basketball, football, women's soccer, women's golf, baseball, softball, men's and women's cross country, field hockey, women's track and field, gymnastics, women's lacrosse, volleyball and wrestling.

Evan Petzold is a sports reporting intern at the Detroit Free Press. Contact him at epetzold@freepress.com or follow him on Twitter @EvanPetzold.
